central_thesis: The Scroll of Set serves as a conduit for the ongoing exploration, development, and practical application of Setian philosophy and magic. It emphasizes individual self-actualization (Xeper) and continuous transformation (Remanifestation) through various magical, psychodramatic, and intellectual means, asserting the individual will as paramount for manifesting an authentic, deified self.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Masques of Initiation: A Psychodramatic Ritual Theatre Production
structure_content.summary: Introduces the Order of the Sepulcher of the Obsidian Masque (OSOM) and its core function of psychodramatic ritual theatre. It announces the upcoming 'Masques of Initiation' for the Set-XIII Conclave, encouraging Setian participation. The OSOM focuses on exploring the energy quality that survives death, Remanifestation, and using ritualistic dramatizations to understand death as a catalyst for Change, alongside developing educational resources on Setian philosophy.

Announces the formation of the Black Phoenix Pylon from the previous Horn of the Bull of Ombos Pylon. Its mission is to uphold initiatory excellence while forging new traditions relevant to Temple of Set philosophy, fostering a magical and intellectual environment conducive to members' progress. The Phoenix imagery symbolizes Xeper and Remanifestation, with Priest Don Webb and Adept Arnold Watson leading.

A brief, poetic account of a dream-like transformative experience involving archetypal elements of darkness, flame, death, and rebirth, culminating in an affirmation of 'new life' and brotherhood, suggestive of an initiatory passage.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gates Of Hell Is Brewing A Cauldron Of Trouble! (Chicago Conference)
structure_content.summary: An announcement for the Chicago Conference, hosted by The Gates of Hell Pylon, inviting Setians to participate in workings, discussions, and social interactions, promising an exciting and fulfilling experience for both new and returning attendees.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book Review: Great Mambo Chicken and the Transhuman Condition
structure_content.summary: Reviews Ed Regis's book, highlighting its relevance to Setians. The book chronicles scientists pursuing a 'transhuman future' through cryonics, immortalism, and nanotechnology. It aligns these scientific endeavors with Setian concepts like the 'Serpent of Eden' and the 'Great Work of the Mad Scientist', viewing the transhuman condition as a welcomed path for Black Magicians seeking to transcend human limitations.

This section debates whether 'power' or 'immortality' is more important for Setians. Contributors like Don Webb III° argue power is a tool for immortality and self-creation, cautioning against its misuse. Nancy Kleinman IV° states their interdependency ('Power without immortality is finite; immortality without power is Hell'). James Lewis VI° sees both as integral, emphasizing power as ability and immortality as a quality of the soul, linked to present awareness and 'Ageless Intelligence', accentuating the 'totality of the soul' and Xeper.

A short, evocative poem depicting a 'Sorceress' on a journey through darkness, fantasy, and madness, using magical invocation ('Song of Conjuring') and calling upon the Morigan, driven by a desire to cross 'Hell' and confront her inner self, implying a profound, perhaps harrowing, self-transformation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Religion and the Self: A Letter
structure_content.summary: Pat Hardy III° discusses the 'religious impulse' in the Temple of Set. While acknowledging that conventional religion can be regressive, he asserts that Setian 'religious trappings' function as psychodramatic tools to expose and dismantle restrictive beliefs, enabling the individual to experience the 'numinous' as the true source of self-value and meaning. This process allows the psyche's divinity to become real, distinguishing Setian practice from uncritical belief systems.

A practical guide by Dennis Mann III° offering legal advice for Setians facing police encounters, emphasizing Constitutional rights, the necessity of legal counsel (preferably on retainer), and the Temple's strict policy against drug use. It advises silence, politeness, documenting incidents, and immediately contacting legal representation or an Elect member, highlighting self-protection within potentially hostile societal contexts.

A poetic lament by James L. Knowles I° expressing profound sorrow and anger ('Dæmon weeps') over various societal injustices and human sufferings, from prenatal addiction and hunger to war and disease. It concludes with a defiant declaration of wrath and the Dæmon's enigmatic smile, suggesting a powerful, transformative response to these grievances.

A poetic invocation by Ronnie Guy Smith I° celebrating the 'dawn of Darkness' and the internal 'Black Flame' as sources of divine power, linked to the 'Essence of Hell' and 'Sun of the Night'. It describes joining the Black Flame, invoking Set, and treading a 'forbidden Path' driven by vengeance and commitment to the 'Darkness of the Flame' for personal transformation.

Vesa Iitti I° details a 'threshold' ritual performed with Adept Laakso, aimed at achieving greater consciousness. The ritual involves shamanic drumming, lighting the Black Flame, and invoking Set as 'Prince of Darkness' and 'Being of Essence non-natural'. It proceeds with summoning elemental forces, interacting with Beelzebub (receiving the Grail of restlessness/invention), Belial (receiving the Pentagram of Set for perfect freedom), and Satan (receiving the Mark of the Beast for Xeper), culminating in the extinguishment of the Black Flame and affirmation of completion.

James B. Severson II° defines Black Meditation as an LHP practice for self-refinement and direct interaction with the 'Gift of Set' (Black Flame). It involves communication, contemplation, reflection, focus, thought, and projection, all centered on conscious will. It aims to establish a silent state of awareness, allowing the Initiate to commune from altered states of consciousness to enhance will. Unlike RHP meditation, it’s not for universal union but for individual expansion, with each meditation having a specific purpose ('Black Tower') and emphasizing conscious control over thought processes.

structure_content.chapter_title: O.K., Everybody Up Against the Wall! (Protocol)
structure_content.summary: Lilith Aquino IV° addresses vital issues of internal Temple protocol, stressing the importance of legible written communication on appropriate stationery and the correct use of formal titles (e.g., Dear Ipsissimus, Magus, Adept, Setian) when addressing Priesthood members or referring to other Initiates. This is presented as a matter of respect and not snobbery, critical for maintaining effective internal communication and decorum.

Michael A. Aquino VI° selects three books for a desert island scenario, representing Setian philosophical principles. Jules Verne's 'Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea' symbolizes the soul's rejection of nature and becoming a supernatural god. Bram Stoker's 'The Jewel of Seven Stars' illuminates true immortality as the 'infinite radiance of one's soul' beyond physical existence or reincarnation. Arnold Federbush's 'The Man Who Lived in Inner Space' depicts regression to pre-human existence, illustrating the body's return to nature while the ka (soul) remains distinct. He briefly mentions Robert W. Chambers’ 'The King in Yellow' as a fourth, unelaborated choice.

An administrative update announcing MCI-Mail's expansion to offer local telephone numbers for direct access in numerous non-North American countries. This enhancement aims to simplify and reduce the cost of accessing MCI's electronic mail service for international subscribers, providing a more convenient alternative to packet switching.

Explores the potential linkage of Glinda (Setian e-mail) to FidoNet, an international e-mail network. Pros include local access without long-distance charges, while cons involve privacy concerns due to multiple 'electronic hands' and limited access to Glinda's features. It acknowledges FidoNet's 'notorious reputation' and stresses the need for stringent procedures to maintain the exclusivity and integrity of Setian electronic traffic.

key_concepts.definition: The central Setian concept meaning 'to become'; a process of continuous self-creation, self-actualization, and individual deification, manifesting one's intrinsic divine potential. It is the active, willful transformation of the self.

A concept closely related to Xeper, implying a renewal or continued expression of the individual's essence beyond physical death, or a process of self-renewal and transformation within current existence.

The intrinsic divine spark or unique consciousness within each individual, considered the 'Gift of Set'. It represents the core of one's conscious self and is the focus of Setian magical work and meditation.

The application of the Black Flame and individual will for self-initiated change and self-actualization, distinct from Right Hand Path (RHP) practices that often seek union with external deities or universal forces. It is characterized by a focus on the self as the primary locus of power and transformation.

A ritualistic technique employed by the Order of the Sepulcher of the Obsidian Masque (OSOM) and the Temple of Set. It involves dramatizations and role-playing to explore and confront profound concepts such as death, personal masks, and life roles, facilitating internal change and insight into the nature of Change.

Within Setian context, immortality is not necessarily endless physical life but rather a quality of the soul, characterized by 'acute awareness and utilization of the moment known as 'now',' and the 'infinite radiance of one's soul by its most magnificent expression,' transcending natural time. It is achieved through Xeper, not through physical reanimation or reincarnation.

The ability to act, control, and manifest will. In Setian philosophy, it is viewed as a necessary tool for attaining immortality and enabling self-creation and interaction with the objective world. However, its misuse can lead to enslavement by external definitions or self-deception.

The experience of the self as the ultimate source of value and meaning. While often misconstrued as religious regression in conventional contexts, in Setian practice, it is a legitimate and valuable means for achieving profound self-actualization and recognizing the psyche's inherent divinity.

A futuristic state where humanity transcends current biological and physical limitations through advanced technology and magical means. It is welcomed by Black Magicians as a path to explore and extend individual existence beyond the 'human condition', aligning with the Setian drive for continuous becoming.

A Left Hand Path meditation technique focused on individual refinement and self-consciousness. It utilizes conscious will to direct awareness inward, interact with the 'Gift of Set' (Black Flame), and explore different states of mental, emotional, spiritual, and physical awareness to enhance one's will. It is characterized by specific purpose and active control, rather than passive absorption or universal union.

practical_system.description: The Scroll outlines a practical system for individual self-deification and consciousness expansion, deeply rooted in the Left Hand Path ethos of the Temple of Set. It emphasizes the cultivation and application of individual will (Black Flame) to achieve continuous self-transformation (Xeper). The system incorporates psychodramatic rituals for confronting and internalizing change, structured meditations for enhancing self-awareness and interacting with one's divine essence, and a philosophical framework that encourages intellectual rigor and personal responsibility. It also includes guidelines for navigating the mundane world while pursuing magical objectives, ensuring both spiritual and practical efficacy.
tools: Legal counsel and knowledge of rights (for mundane protection)
rituals: Psychodramatic Ritual Theatre ('The Masques of Initiation')
Initiatory Ritual (Kalevala Pylon, involving elemental summoning, interactions with Beelzebub, Belial, and Satan, and receiving symbolic items)
Black Meditation (a self-directed LHP meditation for will-induced refinement and consciousness expansion)

relevant_quotes.text: If by power we mean the ability to change the world around us, then power is not something in opposition to immortality, but rather a tool for its attainment. The exercise of power can mean an articulation of the self from the natural order.
Power without immortality is finite; immortality without power is Hell.
The Black Magician will welcome the 'transhuman condition': a future open to human beings who are not content with apologies and justifications for the 'human condition'.
The true essence of Xeper and Remanifestation.

The self reveals itself to the social personality as a numinous guide... The Church of Satan used psychodrama in order to break such mental fetters, and that technique continues to be one aspect of the Temple of Set.

When this state is established, an Initiate of the LHP can commune/investigate and interact from a different state of mental, emotional, spiritual, and physical awareness. This provides the desire of will to enhance itself.

To be man is inevitably, inexorably to reject nature and become one's own super-natural god. That such a being may die 'naturally' is incidental; the totality of its life is no longer nature's to give or to take.

true immortality - not the repulsive reanimation of corpses (anastasis nekron) of Christianity, nor the shallow delusions of reincarnationists - but the infinite radiance of one's soul by its most magnificent expression, and with a serene transcendence of natural time.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' is highly relevant as a primary text for understanding the contemporary philosophy and practical workings within the Temple of Set. It offers direct insights into how core Setian concepts like Xeper and Remanifestation are interpreted and applied, bridging theoretical understanding with practical application through rituals, meditation, and organizational directives. It contextualizes Setian thought within broader occult, esoteric, and even scientific (transhumanism) discourse, demonstrating the dynamic and evolving nature of its philosophy. Furthermore, the practical advice on legal matters and internal protocol underscores the pragmatic and self-preservative aspects vital for practitioners of a marginalized spiritual path.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists primarily of Initiates of the Temple of Set, ranging from newer members (I°) who benefit from foundational explanations and practical guidance (like protocol and legal advice) to higher-degree members (IV°, VI°) who engage with the more advanced philosophical discussions, ritual developments, and organizational announcements. The content assumes a baseline familiarity with Setian terminology and Left Hand Path principles, aiming to deepen understanding, stimulate personal magical work, and foster community engagement and responsibility among its members.
